tn.text: The religious leaders arrest Peter and John after Peter's having healed the man who was born lame.
"approached them" or "came to them"

"They were very angry." The Sadducees, in particular, would have been angry about what Peter and John were saying because they did not believe in resurrection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: proclaiming in Jesus the resurrection from the dead ones
tn.text: Peter and John were saying that God would raise people from the dead in the same way as he had raised Jesus from among the dead. Translate this in a way that allows "the resurrection" to refer to both Jesus' resurrection and the general resurrection of other people.
"from among the dead people"
"The priests, the captain of the temple, and the Sadducees arrested Peter and John"
It was common practice not to question people at night.

tn.ref: the number of the men who believed
tn.text: This refers only to men and does not include how many women or children believed.
"grew to about five thousand"
The rulers question Peter and John who answer without fear.
Here the word "their" refers to the Jewish people as a whole.
This phrase is used here to mark where the action starts. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
This is a reference to the Sanhedrin, the Jewish ruling court, which consisted of these three groups of people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
These two men were members of the high priest's family. This is not the same John as the apostle.
"Who gave you power" (UDB)
Here the word "name" refers to authority. AT: "by whose authority" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Holy Spirit filled peter and he." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:01|2:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: if we this day are being questioned ... by what means was this man made well?
tn.text: Peter asks this question to clarify that this was the real reason that they were on trial. AT: "You are asking us this day ... by what means we made this man well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: we this day are being questioned
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "you are questioning us this day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: by what means was this man made well
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "by what means we have made this man well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: May this be known to you all and to all the people of Israel
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "May all of you and all of the people of Israel know this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: to you all and to all the people of Israel
tn.text: "to you who are questioning us and to all the other people of Israel"

tn.ref: in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth
tn.text: Here the word "name" refers to power and authority. AT: "by the power of Jesus Christ of Nazareth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Peter completes his speech to the Jewish religious rulers that he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:08|4:8]].
Here the word "we" refers to Peter as well as those to whom he is speaking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: Jesus Christ is the stone ... which has been made the head cornerstone
tn.text: Peter is quoting from the Psalms. This is a metaphor that means the religious leaders, like builders, rejected Jesus, but God will made him the most important in his kingdom, as a cornerstone in a building is important. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the word "head" means "most important" or "vital."
"you as builders rejected" or "you as builders rejected as worth nothing"

tn.ref: There is no salvation in any other person
tn.text: This can be stated positively. AT: "He is the only person who is able to save" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: no other name under heaven, that is given among men
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "no other name under heaven that God has given among men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: no other name under heaven, that is given among men, by which
tn.text: The phrase "name ... that is given among men" refers to the person of Jesus. AT: "no other person under heaven, who is given among men, by whom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a way of referring to everywhere in the world. AT: "in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: by which we must be saved
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "which can save us" or "who can save us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the second instance of "they" refers to Peter and John. All other occurrences of the word "they" in this section refer to the Jewish leaders.

tn.ref: the boldness of Peter and John
tn.text: Here the word "boldness" refers to the way in which Peter and John responded to the Jewish leaders. AT: "how boldly Peter and John had spoken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"fearlessness" or "courage"

tn.ref: realized that they were ordinary, uneducated men
tn.text: The Jewish leaders "realized" this because of the way Peter and John spoke. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"understood"
The words "ordinary" and "uneducated" share similar meanings. They emphasize that Peter and John had received no formal training in Jewish law. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the man whom Peter and John had healed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"nothing to say against Peter and John's healing of the man." Here the word "this" refers to what Peter and John had done.
This refers to Peter and John.

tn.ref: What shall we do to these men?
tn.text: The Jewish leaders ask this question out of frustration because they could not think of what to do with Peter and John. AT: "There is nothing that we can do with these men!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: For the fact that a remarkable miracle has been done through them is known to everyone who lives in Jerusalem
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "For everyone who lives in Jerusalem knows that they have done a remarkable miracle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This may be an exaggeration. AT: "almost all of the people who live in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: in order that it spreads no further
tn.text: Here the word "it" refers to any miracles or teaching Peter and John might continue to do. AT: "in order that no more people hear about this miracle" "in order that news of this miracle spreads no further" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: not to speak anymore to anyone in this name
tn.text: Here the word "name" refers to the person of Jesus. AT: "not to speak anymore to anyone about this person, Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "we" refers to Peter and John but not to those whom they are addressing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: Whether it is right in the sight of God
tn.text: Here the phrase "in the sight of God" refers to God's opinion. AT: "Whether God thinks it is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"we must continue to speak" or "we cannot stop speaking"
Verse 22 gives background information about the age of the lame man who was healed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
The Jewish leaders again threatened to punish Peter and John.

tn.ref: They were unable to find any excuse to punish them
tn.text: Although the Jewish leaders threatened Peter and John, they could not find a reason to punish them without causing the people to riot.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "for what Peter and John had done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The man who had experienced this miracle of healing
tn.text: "The man whom Peter and John had miraculously healed"
Speaking together, the people quote a Psalm of David from the Old Testament.
Here the word "they" refers to the rest of the believers, but not to Peter and John.
The phrase "their own people" refers to the rest of the believers. AT: "went to the other believers" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: you who by the Holy Spirit, by the mouth of our father David your servant, said
tn.text: This means that the Holy Spirit caused David to speak or write down what God said.

tn.ref: by the mouth of our father David
tn.text: Here the word "mouth" refers to the words that David spoke or wrote down. AT: "by the words of our father David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Why did the Gentile nations rage, and the peoples imagine useless things?
tn.text: This is a rhetorical question that emphasizes the futility of opposing God. AT: "The Gentile nations should not have raged, and the peoples should not have imagined useless things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These "useless things" consist of plans to oppose God. AT: "the peoples imagine useless things against God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"people groups" or "tribes"
The believers complete their quotation from King David in the Psalms that they began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:23|4:25]].

tn.ref: The kings of the earth set themselves together, and the rulers gathered together against the Lord
tn.text: These two lines mean basically the same thing. The two lines emphasize the combined effort of the earth's rulers to oppose God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
These two phrases mean that they joined their armies together to fight a battle. AT: "set their armies together ... gathered their troops together" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: against the Lord, and against his Christ
tn.text: Here the word "Lord" refers to God. In the Psalms, the word "Christ" refers to the Messiah or God's anointed one.
The believers continue praying.
"this city" refers to Jerusalem.
"Jesus who serves you faithfully"

tn.ref: to do all that your hand and your desire decided
tn.text: Here the word "hand" is used to mean God's power. Additionally, the phrase "your hand and your desire decided" shows God's power and plan. AT: "to do all that you had decided because you are powerful and did all that you planned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The believers complete their prayer that they began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:23|4:24]].

Here the words "look upon" are a request for God to take notice of the way in which the Jewish leaders threatened the believers. AT: "notice how they threaten to punish us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: while you stretch out your hand to heal
tn.text: Here the word "hand" refers to God's power. This is a request for God to show how powerful he is. AT: "while you show your power by healing people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: through the name of your holy servant Jesus
tn.text: Here the word "name" refers to power and authority. AT: "through the power of your holy servant Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Jesus who serves you faithfully." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:27|4:27]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the place ... shook" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they were all filled with the Holy Spirit
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Holy Spirit filled them all." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:01|2:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: were of one heart and soul
tn.text: Here the word "heart" refers to the thoughts and the word "soul" refers to the emotions. Together they refer to the total person. AT: "thought the same way and wanted the same things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"shared their belongings with one another." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:43|2:44]].

tn.ref: great grace was upon them all
tn.text: Possible meanings are: 1) that God was greatly blessing the believers or 2) that the people in Jerusalem held the believers in very high esteem.

tn.ref: owned title to lands or houses
tn.text: This phrase means they had a written record that showed they owned certain property or houses.
"had a deed" or "had a written record"

tn.ref: the money of the things that were sold
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the money that they received from the things that they sold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: laid it at the apostles' feet
tn.text: This means that they presented to money to the apostles. AT: "presented it to the apostles" or "gave it to the apostles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: distribution was made to each believer, according as any one had need
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they distributed the money to each believer who needed it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Luke introduces Barnabas into the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

tn.ref: Joseph ... was given the name Barnabas by the apostles
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The apostles gave Joseph ... the name Barnabas" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "which one may interpret as" or "which means" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The apostles used this to show that Joseph was a person who encouraged others. It is used as though encouragement were a person, Joseph's father.  AT: "a person who always encourages others" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: laid it at the apostles' feet
tn.text: This means that they presented to money to the apostles. AT: "presented it to the apostles" or "gave it to the apostles." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:34|4:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
